name: Axiom of Union
formal_statement: $\forall A \exists B \forall x (x \in B \leftrightarrow \exists Y (Y \in A \land x \in Y))$
informal_description: For any set A (a collection of sets), there exists a set B that contains exactly those elements that belong to at least one set in A. This is the union of all sets in A.

examples.explanation: The union contains elements that are in either set

examples.description: Union of a family of sets
examples.explanation: Take all elements that appear in any of the sets in the collection
Union of no sets is the empty set

counterexamples.description: Not the same as Cartesian product
counterexamples.explanation: Union combines elements, Cartesian product creates ordered pairs

historical_context: Formulated by Zermelo in 1908. Essential for building analysis and topology. Allows construction of infinite sets from finite pieces, enabling mathematical analysis.
pedagogical_notes: Start with finite unions of concrete sets. Common confusion with intersection. Emphasize that union is the 'OR' of set membership. Use Venn diagrams for visualization.

steps: Start with collection A = {A₁, A₂, ..., Aₙ}
Show B satisfies the union property

relationships.description: Uniqueness of union follows from extensionality
Union defined in terms of membership
Topology requires arbitrary unions of open sets
